# Overview 
This is the analysis of white matter dsi studio connectometry for Maze and Loop 

# <span style="color: darkblue;">Methods </span> 

**Participants** 

  * Total number of scans = 120 (males and females)  
  
  * Total scans used in analysis= 118  
  * Excluded subs 329 and 372 from analyses due to bad behavior data and Subject 347 failed quality 
  control check in DSI
   * Several subjects removed because they did not have rad3 score  
<br>

**Maze Accuracy and Path Efficiency**

  * All subjects = 82
  * Men = 22
  * Women = 60
  * Stage
  * Pre = 23
  * Peri = 20 
  * Post = 17
  
  
  **Scan parameters** 

  * Locations from UCSB and UCI
<br>

**QSIprep** 

  * Version used: 0.16.0RC3

  * The following parameters were used
    * dwi_denoise_window **5** 
    * hmc_model **3dSHORE** 
    * hmc-transform **Rigid** 
    * shoreline_iters **2**
<br>
**DSI Studio**

  * Version and tags used via singularity container: **chen-2022-07-31**
  
  * **Parameters** 
    * T-threshold = 2.5
    * Length = 25
    * Permutation = 4,000
    * pruning 4
    * non normalized QA

<br><br>

**Connectronomy analysis methods write up **
<br>

A diffusion spectrum imaging scheme was used, and a total of 128 diffusion sampling were acquired.  
The maximum b-value was 4990 s/mm². The in-plane resolution was 1.8 mm. The slice thickness wasc1.8 mm. The accuracy of b-table orientation was examined by comparing fiber orientations with those of a population-averaged template (Yeh et al. Neuroimage, 2018). The b-table was flipped by 
The diffusion data were reconstructed in the MNI space using q-space diffeomorphic reconstruction
(Yeh et al., Neuroimage, 58(1):91-9, 2011) to obtain the spin distribution function (Yeh et al., IEEE TMI, ;29(9):1626-35, 2010).  A diffusion sampling length ratio of 1.25 was used. The output resolution in diffeomorphic reconstruction was 1.8 mm isotropic. The tensor metrics were calculated using DWI with b-value lower than 1750 s/mm². The quantitative anisotropy was extracted as the local connectome fingerprint (LCF, Yeh et al. PLoS Comput Biol 12(11): e1005203) and used in the connectometry analysis.</p>
<br>

Diffusion MRI connectometry (Yeh et al. NeuroImage 125 (2016): 162-171) was used to derive the correlational tractography that has QA, MD, AD, and RD correlated with Maze Accuracy and path efficiency. A nonparametric Spearman partial correlation was used to derive the correlation, and the effect of sex, age_scan_years, and repo_status was removed using a multiple regression model. The total number of subjects varied on analysis (See Analyses and Final sample sizes above). A T-score threshold of 2.5 was assigned and tracked using a deterministic fiber tracking algorithm (Yeh et al. PLoS ONE 8(11): e80713, 2013) to obtain correlational tractography. A seeding region was placed at whole brain (39,49,29) .
<br>

 The tracks were filtered by topology-informed pruning (Yeh et al. Neurotherapeutics, 16(1), 52-58, 2019) with 4 iteration(s). A length threshold of 25 voxel distance was used to select tracks. To estimate the false discovery rate, a total of 4000 randomized permutations were applied to the group label to obtain the null distribution of the track length.</p>

```{r Sex differences at behavior,echo=FALSE, results='hide',message=FALSE}

# Lets do our variables for sex differences at behaviors
# Maze Accuracy ####

male_acc <- Acc_sub_info %>% filter(sex == "male") %>% select(maze_accuracy_pct)
female_acc <- Acc_sub_info %>% filter(sex == "female") %>% select(maze_accuracy_pct)

male_acc_norm <- shapiro.test(male_acc$maze_accuracy_pct)
female_acc_norm <- shapiro.test(female_acc$maze_accuracy_pct)

sexdif_acc <- wilcox.test(male_acc$maze_accuracy_pct,female_acc$maze_accuracy_pct) %>% broom::tidy() 

## Path EFf All trials ####
male_patheff_all <- Acc_sub_info %>% filter(sex == "male") %>% select(tm_path_efficiencies)
female_patheff_all <- Acc_sub_info %>% filter(sex == "female") %>% select(tm_path_efficiencies)

male_patheff_all_norm <- shapiro.test(male_patheff_all$tm_path_efficiencies)
female_patheff_all_norm <- shapiro.test(female_patheff_all$tm_path_efficiencies)

sexdif_patheff_all <- wilcox.test(male_patheff_all$tm_path_efficiencies,female_patheff_all$tm_path_efficiencies) %>% broom::tidy() 

## Path EFf correct trials ####
 
male_patheff_correct <- Acc_sub_info %>% filter(sex == "male") %>% select(tm_path_efficiencies_acc_only)
female_patheff_correct <- Acc_sub_info %>% filter(sex == "female") %>% select(tm_path_efficiencies_acc_only) %>% na.omit()

male_patheff_correct_norm <- shapiro.test(male_patheff_correct$tm_path_efficiencies_acc_only)
female_patheff_correct_norm <- shapiro.test(female_patheff_correct$tm_path_efficiencies_acc_only)

sexdif_patheff_correct <- wilcox.test(male_patheff_correct$tm_path_efficiencies_acc_only,female_patheff_correct$tm_path_efficiencies_acc_only) %>% broom::tidy()

```
There were no sex differences found between midlife men and women for maze accuracy(p = `r sexdif_acc[2]`), or path efficiency(all trials)(p = `r sexdif_patheff_all[2]`), or path efficiency (correct trials) (p = `r sexdif_patheff_correct[2]`)

## <span style="color: darkorange;"> Maze Accuracy </span>  {.tabset .tabset-dropdown}  
<br><br>

### <span style="color: darkgreen;"> Summary</span>
A total of 82 diffusion MRI scans were included in the connectometry database. For the connectometry analysis, age, sex and repo status were listed as covariates. All subjects displayed Positive Correlations and negative correlations between tracts with QA and Maze accuracy.Tracts in the fornix with MD and RD displayed Positive Correlations relationships with Maze accuracy. AD displayed a negative relationship between tracts in the fornix and maze accuracy. All together the results suggest that increased diffusion (Md and RD) are associated with increased performance in scores in midlife participants and these associations are found in regions associated with spatial navigation. When split by sex, Men displayed a negative association between maze performance and a majority of tracts in the corpus callosum with QA. For AD, RD, and MD, men displayed significant Positive correlations relationships between performance. Altogether it suggests that better maze accuracy is associated with increased diffusion in midlife men.  Women displayed the opposite, tracts in the fornix with QA were positively associated with performance while tracts in the fornix, cingulum, and cerebellum  and  with AD,RD, and MD were negatively associated with performance. Suggesting that more specific diffusion is associated with better maze accuracy. Next, Menopause stages were analyzed separately. Pre menopausal women displayed both positive correlations and negative correlations with QA while tracts with AD,RD and MD displayed negative relationships. Peri menopausal women displayed Positive Correlations associations in tracts with QA, MD, RD, and AD and performance. This suggests that in peri menopasual women, maze accuracy is associated with increased diffusion in tracts on the fornix, cerebellum, and cingulum. Post menopausal women displayed both positive correlations and negative associations between acc and QA. Post menopausal women displayed Positive Correlations and negative associations with QA< MD, RD, and AD and maze accuracy. A majority of tracts in the fornix with AD,MD, and RD were positively associated with maze accuracy 

### QA {.tabset}

#### Summary of results 
There were both Positive Correlations and negative correlations between QA and maze performance when all subjects were included in the analysis. When men were analyzed separately, men displayed more negatively associated correlations between QA and maze performance. Women displayed tracts with predominantly Positive Correlations correlations between QA and performance. When split by menopause stagge, Pre and post displayed both Positive Correlations and negative correlations while peri displayed only Positive Correlations correlations with performance.

### MD {.tabset}
#### Summary of results 
DSI was run on all subjects, with sex and age listed as covariates. There were Positive Correlations correlations between MD values in the Fornix (L&R) and performance. Using a sex stratified apporoach we viewed the relationship between white matter and performance in men and women separately. Men, displayed a majortiy of Positive Correlations correlations between tracts with MD and accuracy. Specifically in regions associated with navigation such as the fornix (L & R).  Women, displayed a majortiy of negative correlations between tracts with MD and accuracy. Specifically in regions associated with navigation such as the fornix (L & R), and cerebelllum. We then investigated the relationship of white matter and performance when splitting by menopause stage. Pre menopause women displayed a majortiy of negative correlations between tracts with MD and accuracy in the fornix(L&R) and corpus callosum. Peri menopause women displayed a majority of Positive Correlations correlations between tracts with MD and accuracy in the fornix(L&R) cerebellum and cingulum. Post Menopause displayed both Positive Correlations and negative relationships between MD and  performance. The majority of tracts with Positive Correlations correlations were in the fornix, while a majority of the negative correlations were found in tracts in the parietal cortex and cerebellum.

#### Summary of results 
Only fornix was negatively associated with performance when all subejcts were analyzed. Fornix and thalamic raditions were positively associated with accuracy.Women displayed negative relationships with tracts int he fornix and cingulum and maze acc. Women in the pre menopasual groups showed tracts were negatively correlated with acc in fornix ,and  corpus callosum. Peri menopausal women showed that a majority of tracts in the fornix, cingulum, and cerebellum were positively associated with Acc. Post menopasual women showed Positive Correlations tracts in the fornix and negative tracts in the cerbebellum.

#### Summary of results 
All subjects analyzed, tracts in the fornix were positively associated with acc. In Men, tracts in the fornix were positvely associated with acc. Women showed tracts in the fornix were negatively associated with acc. Pre menopausal women showed a similar findings to women with negative correlations in tracts in the fornix. Peri menopasual women showed results similar to men, with tracts in the fornix positively associated. Post menopausal women displayed Positive Correlations and negative associations with a majority of Positive Correlations tracts located in the fornix and negative tracts in the cerebellum.

## <span style="color: darkorange;"> Maze Path Efficiency (all trials)  </span>  {.tabset .tabset-dropdown}  

### Summary 

We would expect that lower QA values would correspond to higher PE scores. higher PE scores indicate worse efficiency 

- All subjects
  - Negative correlations in corpus callosum and cingulum. Meaning that those with higher QA values had better efficiency scores ( correct trial only also had negatve only.)
  - MD exhibited negative correlations suggesting lower MD corresponded to higher scores. Lower diffusivity corresponded to worse efficincy  ( same for correct trials only)
  - AD had tracts but they were less than 10. nothing significant for correct trials
  - RD was negative only correlations ( Same with corect trials only : Fornix only)

- Men
  - QA had tracts that were positively and negatively correlated
  - MD was negatively correlated with PE scores. ( Correct only had pos and negative)
  - AD displayed negative correlations suggesting more specific diffusivity corresponded to better efficicency ( correct trials had pos and neg)
  - RD had negative correlations 
  
- Women
  - QA displayed pos and negative correlations but mostly negative ( same for correct trials)
  - MD displayed pos and negative correlations but mostly negative corrs. (correct only did not have any correlations
  - AD  displayed pos and negative correlations but mostly negative corrs (correct only did not have any correlations)
  -RD displayed pos and negative correlations but mostly negative corrs (correct showed same po/neg)
  
- Pre
  - QA displayed pos and negative correlations but mostly negative ( same for correct trials)
  - MD displayed pos and negative correlations 
  - AD displayed negative correlations 
  - RD displayed negative correlations 
  
- Peri
  - QA displayed negative correlations 
  - MD displayed pos and negative correlations with tracts in the fornix displaying a pos relationship
  - AD displayed pos and negative correlations with tracts in the fornix displaying a pos relationship
  - RD displayed pos and negative correlations with tracts in the fornix displaying a pos relationship
  
- Post
  - QA displayed negative correlations 
  - MD displayed pos and negative correlations 
  - AD displayed pos and negative correlations with most being negative
  - RD displayed pos and negative correlations
  
- Peri and Post
  - QA displayed negative correlations 
  - MD displayed pos and negative correlations 
  - AD displayed positive
  - RD displayed pos and negative correlations but mostly positive
  
<br><br><br><br><br><br><br>

## <span style="color: darkorange;"> Maze Path Efficiency (correct trials only)  </span>  {.tabset .tabset-dropdown}

### Summary 

ALl subs  
- QA was negatively correlated with PE in corpuss callosum   
- MD was negatively correlated with PE in fornix  
- AD was not significant  
- RD was negatively correlated with PE  in fornix   

men    
- QA was had a majority of negative corrleations   
- MD was positively and negatively  correlated with PE  
- AD was positively correlated with PE   
- RD was positively and negatively  correlated with PE  

women
- QA was negatively correlated with pe in the cingulum  
- RD, AD, and MD were not significant  

Pre  
- QA was negatively correlated with pe in the cingulum  
- MD was positively correlated with pe   
- AD was negatively correlated   
- RD had neg and positive cors  

Peri  
- QA was negatively correlated with pe in the cingulum  
- MD was positively correlated with pe   
- AD was positively correlated with pe   
- RD was positively correlated with pe   

Post  
- QA was positively correlated with pe   
- MD was negatively correlated with pe   
- AD was negatively correlated with pe   
- RD was negatively correlated with pe   

Peri and Post  
- QA was positively and negatively correlated with pe   
- MD was positively correlated with pe   
- AD was positively correlated with pe   
- RD was negatively and positively correlated with pe
